embeds.title: Safeguard
embeds.description:
Common Skill / 1 :energy_auto: / The Automaton / Downfall

Gain 7 (9) **Block** :p_block:.
**Encode.**

embeds.title: Iron Wave
embeds.description:
Common Attack / 1 :red_energy: / The Ironclad / Slay the Spire

Gain 5 (7) **Block** :p_block:.
Deal 5 (7) damage.

messages.content: literally every function is this card but on crack
The orbs they summon disrupt the opponent and he buffs/does a double attack and then the hyper beam
and you don't have to take risks or think or anything
There is planning in the order of which the cards are encoded
lol
Like terminator for instance
You also could put buggy mess before or after go to to either deal with the dazed now or later
It's not all one note
I can say that from my multiple a20 auto runs it barely matters in combats
it might matter in 5% of functions.
Sure it's simple and you realistically could just make iron waves and win but there is more you can do with functions

One of the best common encode cards, specifically because it provides block rather than attack. Many of the common encode cards are focused on dealing damage, so have access to 1 or 2 copies of safeguard can help round your functions out nicely. It also feels much better to play with than delayed guard, which is fairly awkward on a character that really needs to buy time to get their setup online, and can't usually afford to wait for a delayed effect. Null pointer requires some pretty specific support to use as a source of block, constructor is less efficient and higher rarity (though it can be better with the right support). Fragment is very solid, though it is worse at giving specifically block, and is uncommon. Boost is really strong, but is also higher rarity and more expensive. I really like upgrading this card as well to improve its efficiency, it's technically a +4 since you get the effect again after making a function (If you wait to finish create the function, it's also a way you can "blur" some block between turns). 

Not usually a great pickup in act 1, since it's weak into 2 of the elites, and blocking/scaling isn't really that useful in most of the hallway fights. However, once you are feeling comfortable with your elites or have passed gremlin nob, I would snap this up ASAP. It's great for the entire rest of the run, and one of your best mitigation tools. Pairs very nicely with fortify, oddly smooth stone, prickly shields, sentient form, and mallet. Notable that any dexterity you gain will affect this twice as you are making the function, which makes smooth stone very powerful with it.

like uh.... apply weak with your iron wave.... or uh......... apply vulnerable with your iron wave..... or uh.... add an iron wave onto your iron waves with summon orb...... or uh make your iron wave do poison damage
these are all very different

they literally all play the exact same and you can shove any three random encode cards into a function and it's probably going to look like <iron wave>

messages.content: Actually it's more like pummel than iron wave tbh
Since there's only 4 encode blocks
Actually 5
Cause of fragment being both
Sometimes you get a ludicrously efficient attack instead of an iron wave
But it costs 1 so playing it every time you draw it is still a no brainer
It's hard to argue against this character being mindless
I definitely don't see how functions are supposed to represent high risk high reward, could you elaborate?

I think a hyperbeam archetype just wouldn't work out in a character's kit. I think functions, with a bit of tweaking could work, but I don't see a way you could really make a character based around "big attacks with downsides next turn". That's called slime boss tackles and everyone knows they aren't good.
the actual boss
functions are just an idea that doesn't take much inspiration from the boss
status can be fixed to make it more like that by removing bug barrage and repulsor rework, but functions are just way too safe on a character that should be about explosive power and consequence

With functions the main issue (imo) is that the amount of work you put in to make them does not justify the power they have. An idea I've had and shared (people were not a fan of it though) is functions exhausting, and encode cards just encode a copy of a card (make some of them like boost exhaust too) and all of a sudden functions still keep their strength but you have to work for it, plus deck thinning isn't as easy

now that I think about it:
This card is probably the linear search of Auto
a staple tool that will be used very often
this is an idea I generally like
~~what to do with backtrace then~~
if functions only worked once that would fit the whole "build up to a super attack" concept better than the current implementation. And also probably just be less inherently overpowered
I think if you did that you'd probably want to have compile effects in general only apply the first time it's cast each fight, since probably half of them are things you'd normally want to exhaust.
that also opens up room for a new rare similar to the "becomes a power" one which would just have the effect of "this function doesn't exhaust".
or maybe "next function you play doesn't exhaust", possibly just as a bonus on a rare attack
point is it's a very interactable mechanic
remove
very true
That's why I mentioned some exhausting, could be a way to do that without making a new keyword
well you don't need a new keyword if it's a blanket change to all compile effects
You just need to modify the existing keyword
The compile error cards would sort of be buffed by that? Except really it's more like they're not getting nerfed as hard as all the other encode cards
not the “bad thing happens once” compiles
only the “function bad” compiles
yeah I was mostly thinking the stuff like "gives you statuses"
the ones with "the function gets messed up" compiles would just need to be exhaust cards
or vanish
it's certainly a big rework
It is a decent rework, but it still keeps a pretty similar framework and most cards don't really need much changing

automation even has a ton of support for just spamming functions (stuff like summon orbs). Making an acutal strategy can be weaker then just spamming high value cards.
as for safe guard. It sure is a safe card! most runs are taking 1 of these and you can take more if you really want
